But, of course, there’s a lot more to IPv6 than ‘just’ switching everything over. A lot of systems in the world still haven’t adopted it after nearly 25 years, and although software support is virtually a requirement these days, that doesn’t mean it’s widely enabled. content.text:
Here's a roundup of this week's key generative AI news:

## Major Business & Industry Moves

**Yann LeCun launches AMI Labs** — Less than a month after leaving Meta after 12 years, the Turing Award winner is raising €500 million at a $3.5 billion valuation for his new Paris-based startup. AMI Labs will focus on "world models" — AI systems that understand physics and plan complex actions rather than simply predicting the next word.

**Enterprise AI spending hits $37 billion** — According to Menlo Ventures, enterprise generative AI spending grew 3.2x year-over-year. Coding tools dominate at $4 billion (jumping from $550M last year), with at least 10 products now generating over $1 billion in ARR.

## New Model & Product Releases

**OpenAI releases GPT Image 1.5** — The updated image generation model delivers up to 4x faster generation and better instruction-following. A new Images tab in ChatGPT is being pitched as an "idea generator."

**Nvidia launches Nemotron 3** — The new open reasoning models are optimized for agentic AI systems, coming in Nano (30B), Super (100B), and Ultra (500B) sizes. The Nano version supports up to one million tokens of context.

## The "Hype Correction" Narrative

MIT Technology Review declared 2025 "a year of reckoning" for generative AI. The botched launch of GPT-5 in August triggered a major vibe shift — AI researcher Yannic Kilcher called it "the Samsung Galaxy era of LLMs," comparing AI progress to the incremental smartphone updates we see today.

## Google's Strong Finish

Google's Gemini app grew to 650 million monthly active users (up from 350 million in March), and their "Nano Banana" image generation feature became so popular it nearly overwhelmed their infrastructure. Alphabet stock is up 62% this year, outperforming all megacap peers.

## Government & Regulation

**Pentagon rolls out GenAI.mil** — The DoD deployed a new platform providing OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and xAI tools to almost its entire workforce, with a mandate to incorporate AI into daily workflows.

**Adobe faces class-action lawsuit** — Plaintiffs allege Adobe misused creators' uploaded work to train Firefly without explicit consent.

Given your work on agentic AI governance frameworks, the Nemotron 3 release and the Pentagon's GenAI.mil rollout might be particularly relevant — both touch on enterprise deployment patterns and the operational challenges of agentic systems at scale.

content.text:
What you’re really trying to achieve isn’t “edit shortcuts in a text editor” for its own sake — it’s “Shortcuts-as-code” so you can (a) have ChatGPT generate them, (b) version-control them, and (c) maintain large automations without the drag-and-drop UI. That’s a solvable problem today, but not by editing Apple’s exported `.shortcut` files directly in VS Code in a clean, official way.

Here’s what the research says.

Apple’s native format is hostile to hand-editing (and that’s by design)
Shortcuts exported as `.shortcut` are essentially serialized property lists (plists) describing arrays of actions (you’ll often see keys like `WFWorkflowActions`). ([Cherri][1])
Even worse: since iOS 15 (and macOS 12), Apple requires shortcuts to be “signed” to import/share/run, and the official signing flow relies on Apple validation (the macOS `shortcuts sign` command explicitly notes Apple receives a copy for validation). ([Cherri][2])
Net: you can technically reverse-engineer/edit the plist, but you’ll still need a signing step after any change, which is exactly what makes “just edit the file in a text editor” painful (and often impractical without extra tooling).

What people actually do instead (the practical solutions)

1. Use a text-based language that compiles to Shortcuts (best match for “let ChatGPT generate it”)
   Cherri is currently one of the most complete “Shortcuts-as-code” approaches: you write `.cherri` files in a normal editor (VS Code supported), compile to `.shortcut`, and then sign either on macOS automatically or via a remote signer / signing server on Windows/Linux. ([Cherri][3])
   Key point for you (no macOS): Cherri explicitly supports using HubSign or a custom signing server on non-macOS platforms. ([Cherri][3])
   There’s also a web playground to write/compile/export from the browser, which is a big deal if you want to stay iPad/iPhone-centric. ([Cherri][3])

How this solves your “closed scripts” problem:

* Your “source of truth” becomes text files (great for Git).
* ChatGPT can generate Cherri code reliably.
* The compiled `.shortcut` becomes a build artifact you import onto iOS.

2. Jellycuts / OpenJelly (text IDE focused on Shortcuts)
   Jellycuts is an iOS/iPadOS app + “Jelly” language meant specifically to write shortcuts in text and compile them into real Shortcuts. ([Honeypot][4])
   This is also compatible with the “ChatGPT writes code” model (ChatGPT outputs Jelly code; you paste and compile). It’s more “on-device developer experience” than “plain text file format,” but it achieves the same outcome: you’re no longer trapped in Apple’s block editor.

3. Shortcutor (GUI editor on Windows/Linux/macOS)
   Shortcutor is a third-party desktop editor that gives you mouse/keyboard editing, copy/paste across shortcuts, and device export via a helper shortcut + QR workflow. ([Shortcutor.com][5])
   This doesn’t give you a clean text DSL, but it does solve “editing is painful on iPhone/iPad” and makes maintenance faster.

4. Older DSLs exist, but many are stale
   ScPL exists as a text language, but community notes indicate it hasn’t kept up with newer iOS Shortcuts actions, so it’s generally not the best bet in 2025 unless your needs are very narrow. ([GitHub][6])

My recommendation for your exact setup (no macOS)
If your main pain is “I want ChatGPT to create shortcuts and I want them in Git”:

* Use Cherri as your “Shortcut source code,” because it’s explicitly designed for large, maintainable shortcut projects and has a non-mac signing story. ([Cherri][3])
  A simple workflow looks like:

1. ChatGPT generates a `.cherri` file (you keep it in Git)
2. Compile + sign using `--hubsign` (or your own signing server)
3. Import the resulting `.shortcut` on iPhone via Files/iCloud/email as described in the Cherri docs ([Cherri][3])

If you want to do everything on iPad/iPhone with minimal “toolchain”:

* Use the Cherri web playground (browser) or Jellycuts (app). ([Cherri][3])

One important caution: any remote signing service implies uploading your shortcut file to someone else’s server for signing. Treat shortcuts like code: don’t bake secrets into them; use import questions / prompts so you enter keys on-device after import.

A better query to get what you want from ChatGPT
Instead of “make me an Apple Shortcut,” ask for a text-source shortcut in a DSL:

“Write a Cherri shortcut for iOS that: [goal]. Constraints: only built-in Shortcuts actions (no third-party apps), use import questions for any API keys, add comments, and keep it modular (functions). Output only valid `*.cherri` code.”

If you tell me one concrete shortcut you’d like (e.g., “share selected text from any app into my Windows15 handoff queue”), I’ll draft it as Cherri source first — that’s the quickest path to making ChatGPT actually useful for Shortcuts creation on your setup.

[1]: https://cherrilang.org/compiler/file-format.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Shortcut File Format | Cherri"
[2]: https://cherrilang.org/compiler/signing.html "Signing | Cherri"
[3]: https://cherrilang.org/language/getting-started.html "Getting Started | Cherri"
[4]: https://honeypot.net/2021/05/16/review-jellycuts.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Review: Jellycuts"
[5]: https://shortcutor.com/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Shortcutor.com - Edit and manage Siri Shortcuts"
[6]: https://github.com/pfgithub/scpl?utm_source=chatgpt.com "pfgithub/scpl: text language for writing ios shortcuts faster"
